   The Codified Ordinances and other documents that appear in this FOLIO Infobase
may not reflect the most current legislation adopted by the Municipality. The
Codified Ordinances are provided for informational purposes only and should not
be relied upon as the definitive authority for local legislation.  Additionally,
the formatting and pagination of the posted documents vary from the formatting
and pagination of the official copy.  The official printed copy of the Codified
Ordinances should be consulted prior to any action being taken.
 
     For further information regarding the official version of any portion of the
Codified Ordinances in this FOLIO Infobase, please contact the Municipality
directly.
 
 
CERTIFICATION
 
   I, L. Paul Ingram, Mayor of St. Marys, West Virginia, pursuant to West
Virginia Code 8-11-4(b), hereby certify that the general and permanent
ordinances of the City of St. Marys, West Virginia, as revised, rearranged,
compiled, renumbered as to sections, recodified and printed herewith in
component codes are correctly set forth and constitute the Codified Ordinances
of the City of St. Marys, West Virginia, 1985, as amended to  February 11,
2022.

EDITOR'S NOTE
   The arrangement and numbering of the Codified Ordinances into component
codes, chapters, articles and sections are based on an adoption of the decimal
numbering system which is in accord with the best accepted practice in
instituting a codification.  Each section is self-identifying as to code,
article and section number.  For example, 305.06 indicates that the code number
is 3, the article number is 305 (or the 5th article within code 3), and the
section number is .06.  The code and article numbers appear left of the
decimal, with the code number preceding the first two digits left of the
decimal, and the article number being all digits left of the decimal.  The
section number appears right of the decimal.  As another example, 113.10
indicates the code number is 1, the article number is 113 (or the 13th article
within code 1), and the section number is.10.
   This numbering system has the advantage of inherent flexibility in allowing
for an almost endless amount of expansion.  Codes, chapters, and articles
initially are odd-numbered, thus reserving the use of even numbers for future
legislation.  Sections within articles are consecutively numbered, except that
penalty provisions are usually assigned the number .99.  Newly created sections
subsequent to the original codification may be indicated by three digits right
of the decimal in the event the law properly belongs between two consecutively
numbered sections.  For example, newly created 575.061, 575.062 and 575.063
follow 575.06 and precede 575.07 to be placed in their logical position.
   Section histories enable a user to trace the origin of the law contained in
the section.  The history indicates the derivation by reference to either its
passage date and the ordinance number originally assigned to it at that time,
or to its inclusion in any prior code.  Sections without histories indicate
that the section contains new matter which was ordained by the Adopting
Ordinance which enacts the Codified Ordinances.
   The Comparative Section Table is included to show the disposition of every
ordinance included in the Codified Ordinances.  It indicates whether a given
ordinance was consolidated with another into one section or split into two or
more sections.  Cross references direct the user to subject matter reasonably
related to material contained within a given article.

CROSS REFERENCES
See sectional histories for similar State law

Codification of ordinances - see W. Va. Code 8-11-4(b)
 
101.01  DESIGNATION; CITATION; HEADINGS.
   (a)    All ordinances of a permanent and general nature of the Municipality
as revised, recodified, rearranged, renumbered and consolidated into component
codes, chapters, articles and sections shall be known and designated as the
Codified Ordinances of St. Marys, West Virginia, 1985, for which designation
"Codified Ordinances" may be substituted. Code, chapter, article and section
headings do not constitute any part of the law as contained in the Codified
Ordinances. Codified Ordinances shall have the same meaning as City Code.
 
   (b)    All references to codes, chapters, articles and sections are to such
components of the Codified Ordinances unless otherwise specified. Any component
code may be referred to and cited by its name, such as the "Traffic Code".
Sections may be referred to and cited by the designation "Section" followed by
the number, such as "Section
101.01".
 
101.02  GENERAL DEFINITIONS.
   As used in the Codified Ordinances, unless otherwise expressly provided or
the context otherwise requires:
   (a)    Council means the legislative authority of the Municipality.
   (b)    County means Pleasants County, West Virginia.
   (c)    Land or lands and real estate or real property  includes lands,
tenements and hereditaments, and all rights thereto and interests therein
except chattel interests.
   (d)    Laws of the State  includes the Constitution of the State and the
Constitution of the United States, and treaties and laws made in pursuance
thereof.
      (WVaC 2-2-10)
   (e)    Municipality or City means the City of St. Marys, West Virginia.
   (f)    Offense includes every act or omission for which a fine, forfeiture
or punishment is imposed by law. (WVaC 2-2-10)
   (g)    Owner, when applied to property, includes any part owner, joint owner
or tenant in common of the whole or part of such property.
   (h)    Person or whoever includes corporations, societies, associations and
partnerships.
   (i)    Personal estate or personal property includes goods, chattels, real
and personal, money, credits, investments and the evidences thereof.
   (j)    Preceding, succeeding or following used in reference to any section
or sections of an article means next preceding, next succeeding or next
following that in which such reference is made. (WVaC 2-2-10)
   (k)    Premises, as applied to property, includes land and building.
   (l)    Property or estate embraces both real and personal estate. (WVaC 2-2-
10)
   (m)    Public place includes any street, sidewalk, park, cemetery, school
yard, body of water or watercourse, public conveyance or any other place for
the sale of merchandise, public accommodation or amusement.
   (n)    Registered mail includes certified mail.
   (o)    State means the State of West Virginia or any department, division,
commission, board, educational or other institution of the State.
   (p)    Street includes alleys, avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads, highways,
viaducts and all other public thoroughfares within the Municipality.
   (q)    Tenant or occupant, as applied to premises, includes any person
holding a written or oral lease, or who actually occupies the whole or any part
of such premises alone or with others.
   (r)    Written or in writing includes any representation of words, letters
or figures, whether by printing, engraving, writing or otherwise. But when the
signature of any person is required, it must be in his own proper handwriting,
or his mark, attested, proved or acknowledged. (WVaC 2-2-10)
 
101.03  RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (a)    General Rule.  All words and phrases shall be construed and
understood according to the common and approved usage of the language, but
technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and
appropriate meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to
such peculiar and appropriate meaning.
 
   (b)    Gender and Plural.  A word importing the singular number only may be
applied to several persons or things, as well as to one person or thing; a word
importing the plural number only may be applied to one person or thing as well
as to several; and a word importing the masculine gender only may be applied to
females as well as males.
(WVaC 2-2-10)
 
   (c)    Computation of Time.  The time within which an act is to be done
shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last, or if the
last be a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday it shall also be excluded.
(WVaC 2-2-3)
 
   (d)    Joint Authority.  Words purporting to give a joint authority to three
or more persons confer such authority upon a majority of them, and not upon any
less number.
(WVaC 2-2-10)
 
   (e)    Exceptions.  The rules of construction shall not apply to any law
which contains any express provision excluding such construction, or when the
subject matter or context of such law may be repugnant thereto.
 
101.04  REPEAL OF REPEALING ACT; EFFECT OF REPEAL.
   (a)    When a law which has repealed another is itself repealed, the former
law shall not be revived without express words for that purpose.  (WVaC 2-2-9)
 
   (b)    The repeal of a law, or its expiration by virtue of any provision
contained therein, shall not affect any offense committed, or penalty or
punishment incurred, before the repeal took effect or the law expired, save
only that the proceedings thereafter shall conform as far as practicable to the
laws in force at the time such proceedings take place, unless otherwise
specially provided; and that if any penalty or punishment be mitigated by the
new law, such new law may, with the consent of the party affected thereby, be
applied to any judgment pronounced after it has taken effect. (WVaC 2-2-8)
 
   (c)    The repeal by any provision of the Codified Ordinances of an
ordinance validating previous acts, contracts or transactions shall not affect
the validity of such acts, contracts or transactions, but the same shall remain
as valid as if there had been no such repeal, but no further.  (WVaC 2-2-11)
 
101.05  CONSTRUCTION OF SECTION REFERENCES.
   When reference is made to any section or group of sections of the Codified
Ordinances, such reference shall extend to and include any amendment of or
supplement to the section or group of sections so referred to or any section or
sections hereafter enacted in lieu thereof; and unless otherwise provided,
whenever a reference to a section or group of sections is made in any amendment
or supplement to any section of the Codified Ordinances hereafter enacted, such
reference shall be deemed to refer to the section or sections as the same shall
then stand or as thereafter amended. 
   Whenever in a penalty section reference is made to a violation of a section
or an inclusive group of sections, such reference shall be construed to mean a
violation of any provision of the section or sections included in such
reference.
   References in the Codified Ordinances to action taken or authorized under
designated sections of the Codified Ordinances include, in every case, action
taken or authorized under the applicable legislative provision which is
superseded by the Codified Ordinances.
   If a section refers to a series of numbers or letters, the first and the
last number or letters in the series are deemed to be included.
 
101.06  ACTS BY AGENT OR DEPUTY.
   When a section requires that an act be done by an officer or person, it
shall be sufficient if it be done by his agent or deputy, unless it be such as
cannot lawfully be done by deputation.  (WVaC 2-2-5)
 
101.07  CONFLICTING PROVISIONS.
   If the provisions of different codes, articles or sections of the Codified
Ordinances conflict with or contravene each other, the provisions bearing the
latest passage date shall prevail. If the conflicting provisions bear the same
passage date, the conflict shall be construed so as to be consistent with the
meaning or legal effect of the questions of the subject matter taken as a
whole.
 
101.08  SEPARABILITY.
   Each section of the Codified Ordinances and every part of each section is an
independent section and part of a section, and the holding of any section or a
part thereof to be unconstitutional, void or ineffective for any cause does not
affect the validity or constitutionality of any other section or part thereof.
 
101.09  EXTRATERRITORIAL EXERCISE OF POWERS AND AUTHORITY.
   Wherever the powers and authority granted in the City ordinances cannot be
reasonably and efficiently exercised by confining the exercise thereof within
the corporate limits of the Municipality, the powers and authority of the
Municipality shall extend beyond the corporate limits to the extent necessary
to the reasonably efficient exercise of such powers and authority within the
corporate limits. Such powers and authority, unless provided in the West
Virginia Code or elsewhere in law, shall not, however, extend more than one
mile beyond the corporate limits, and such powers and authority shall not
extend into the corporate limits of another Municipality without the consent of
the governing body thereof.
(Passed 12-8-76. )
 
101.99  GENERAL PENALTY.
   Whenever, in the Codified Ordinances or in any ordinance of the
Municipality, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an
offense, or whenever the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any
act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is otherwise
provided, whoever violates any such provision shall be fined not more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00).  Each day any such violation continues shall
constitute a separate offense.  (Ord. 1990-5.  Passed 5-1-90.)
 
ARTICLE 103
Elections
103.01   Registration; records.
103.02   Procurement and return of  registration records.
103.03   Boundaries of voting  precincts.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Description of wards - see CHTR. §3
Election procedures - see CHTR. §8 et seq.
Municipal elections - see W. Va. Code 3-1-2a
Municipal voting precincts - see W. Va. Code 3-1-6
Municipal precinct registration records - see W. Va. Code 3-1-27
Absentee voting in municipal elections - see W. Va. Code 3-3-13
Special elections - see W. Va. Code 8-5-15a
 
 
103.01  REGISTRATION; RECORDS.
   (a)    Only persons who are bona fide residents of the City and are
registered to vote as provided by law shall be entitled to vote in any
Municipal election, and the provisions of West Virginia Code 60-7-3, the
"Permanent Registration Law, " so far as applicable to Municipalities, is
hereby adopted to govern any election in the City.
   (b)    The Municipal registration records for the Pleasants County precincts
which are within the City, as they are kept and maintained by the County
Commission of Pleasants County, shall be the official registration of voters
for any municipal election, and only those persons so registered shall be
eligible to vote.
(Passed 11-3-81.)
103.02  PROCUREMENT AND RETURN OF REGISTRATION RECORDS.
   (a)    All elections of the City shall be held in accordance with and
subject to the provisions of the permanent registration law of the State.
   (b)    At least three days prior to each primary or other election of the
City, it shall be the duty of the City Clerk to procure from the office of the
Clerk of the County Court of Pleasants County, the Municipal registration
records necessary for the conduct of such election. Such records shall, within
ten days after the date of the Municipal election, be returned to the office of
the Clerk of the County Court by the City Clerk.
   (c)    In case of a contested election, the registration record of any
challenged voter may be  obtained from the Clerk of the County Court by Council
to determine the contest. Such records shall be returned by the City Clerk on
to the office of the Clerk of the County Court within a reasonable time after
the contest shall have been finally decided.
(1972 Code §5-1)
103.03  BOUNDARIES OF VOTING PRECINCTS.
   For the purpose of all Municipal elections of the City, the voting precincts
in the City shall coincide with the boundaries of the voting precincts as fixed
by the County Court of Pleasants County for all State and County elections,
each County precinct and each part of a County precinct within the City shall
constitute a separate voting precinct of the City.
(1972 Code §5-2)
ARTICLE 105
Purchasing Procedures

CROSS REFERENCES

105.01  OPENING OF BIDS.
   All bids respecting the letting of a contract or contracts for work or
services to be performed for the City, or for the acquisition of any item of
personal property or chattel by the City, shall be opened in the presence of
the persons of Council assembled, or a quorum thereof, unless otherwise
provided in specific instances by majority vote of Council or a quorum thereof.
(Passed 10-9-79.)
ARTICLE 107
Official Standards
107.01   Official City time.
107.02   Official copy of Codified Ordinances.
107.03   Sale of Codified Ordinances.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Legal holidays - see W. Va. Code 2-2-1

101.03(c)
 
 
107.01  OFFICIAL CITY TIME.
   Whenever any time or hour of the day is mentioned in the Codified
Ordinances, or in any ordinance of the City hereafter adopted, the time or hour
shall be construed to mean Eastern Standard Time, or Daylight Saving Time if
then in use in the City, and such Eastern Standard Time, or Daylight Saving
Time if then in use in the City, is hereby adopted as the official standard
time of the City.
(1972 Code §1-8)
107.02  OFFICIAL COPY OF CODIFIED ORDINANCES.
   One copy of the Codified Ordinances shall be certified by the City Clerk as
correct and official and shall be placed and kept permanently on file in the
office of the City Clerk. No person shall remove such copy of the Codified
Ordinances from the office of the City Clerk. Any person violating this section
shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
(1972 Code §1-9)
107.03  SALE OF CODIFIED ORDINANCES.
   The City Clerk is hereby authorized to sell any copies of the Codified
Ordinances, not needed for the use of the city officers, at such price as may
be fixed by resolution of Council. (1972 Code §1-10)

ARTICLE 121
Council
121.01   Powers generally.
121.02   Time and place of meetings.
121.03   Meetings falling on holidays.

121.10   Preservation of order.
121.11   Rescinded action.
121.12   Addressing meetings.
121.13   Suspension of rules.
121.14   Robert's Rules of Order.
121.15   Disrespect or contemptuous conduct toward Council.
121.16   Rental of City building.
121.17   Officers declared agents of Council; reports.
121.18   Assignment of additional duties; compensation.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Quorum - see CHTR. §16
Records - see CHTR. §17
Powers and duties of Council - see CHTR. §22 et seq.
Open meeting law - see W. Va. Code Art. 6-9A
General powers - see W. Va. Code Art. 8-12
Adoption of rules - see W. Va. Code Art. 8-12-5(45)
 
 
121.01  POWERS GENERALLY.
   (a)    Council shall possess and exercise all executive, legislative, and
judicial powers conferred upon cities, towns and villages by the general law of
the State of West Virginia, and by the Charter of the City. Council shall make
all orders for the construction of any improvement or building, and for the
doing of any work, except where authority for the doing of such work has been
expressly conferred upon another designated official. Council shall levy  all
taxes, proportion and apportion all funds and debts, and allow all bills,
accounts, payrolls and claims and direct payment thereof.
   (b)    The Council shall make all assessments in cases of street
improvements, sewers and other works, improvements and repairs for which
assessments may be laid. Council shall make and authorize the making of all
contracts, and no contract shall bind or be obligatory upon the City, unless
made either by ordinance or resolution adopted by Council and expressly
authorized by ordinance or resolution adopted by Council.
(Passed 8-1-78. )
121.02  TIME AND PLACE OF MEETINGS.
   Council shall hold one regular meeting every two weeks and, except as
otherwise herein provided, such regular meeting shall be held on the first and
third Tuesdays of each month in Council Chambers, in the City Building. A
notice shall be posted by the City Recorder at the front door of the City
Building of the time and place fixed and entered of record by Council for the
holding of regularly scheduled sessions. If a particular regularly scheduled
session is cancelled, a notice of such cancellation shall be posted at the
front door of the City Building. (Passed 8-1-78; 10-7-80.)
121.03  MEETINGS FALLING ON HOLIDAYS.
   Whenever a legal holiday falls on a Tuesday, such regular meeting shall be
held at the aforesaid hour and place on the Wednesday following such holiday.
(Passed 8-1-78.)
121.04  MEETINGS NOT HELD IN COUNCIL CHAMBERS.
   In the event that any regular meeting cannot be held in Council Chambers, it
shall be held at such other convenient place in the City as may be designated
of record by a majority of the members of Council and such persons entitled to
seats therein who may be absent at the time such other meeting place is so
designated shall be so notified. (Passed 8-1-78.)
121.05  SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   (a)    Special meetings of Council shall be held upon the request of any two
members of Council. Such request shall be in writing, signed by the members
asking the same, and shall be filed with the City Recorder in such time as to
permit the giving of not less than forty-eight hours notice of such special
meeting to each member and each person entitled to a seat in Council and it
shall thereupon become the duty of the City Recorder to give such notice.
   (b)    A notice shall be posted by the City Recorder at the front door of
the City Building at least two days before a special session is to be held,
stating the time,  place and  purpose for which such special meeting shall be
held. If the special session is cancelled, a notice of such cancellation shall
be posted at the front door of the City Building.
(Passed 8-1-78; 10-7-80.)
121.06  OPEN MEETINGS.
   All meetings of Council, whether regular or special, to which any person not
a City  officer is admitted, shall be open to the public.
(Passed 8-1-78.)
121.07  PRESIDING OFFICER.
   The Mayor shall be the presiding officer of Council at all regular or
special meetings  and when Council meets as a committee of the whole.  (Passed
8-1-78.)
121.08  CLERK OF COUNCIL; MEETINGS.
   The City Recorder shall be the Clerk of Council and shall keep the minutes 
thereof and record the same in a well-bound book, which minutes shall be signed
by the Recorder, and when approved at a subsequent meeting of Council, shall be
signed by the Mayor.
(Passed 8-1-78.)
121.09  QUORUM.
   A majority of all of the members of Council must be present to constitute a
quorum for the transaction of business at every regular or special meeting.
(Passed 8-1-78.)
121.10  PRESERVATION OF ORDER.
   The Presiding Officer shall take the chair at the hour appointed for Council
to meet, and having called the members to order, shall preserve order and
decorum, and in case of disturbance or disorderly conduct in the City Building,
may cause the same to be cleared. (Passed 8-1-78.)
121.11  RESCINDED ACTION.
   No vote or action of Council shall be rescinded at any special meeting
unless there be present at such special meeting as many members of Council as
were present at the meeting when such vote or action was taken, as provided by
statute.
(Passed 8-1-78.)
121.12  ADDRESSING MEETINGS.
   No person other than the Mayor or a member of Council or other Municipal
officer or employee shall address that body at any regular or special meeting
of Council except upon consent of a majority of the members present.  (Passed
8-1-78.)
121.13  SUSPENSION OF RULES.
   The rules of order, other than those prescribed, may be suspended at any
time by consent of a majority of the members present at any meeting.
(Passed 8-1-78.)
121.14  ROBERT'S RULES OF ORDER.
   Except when in conflict with the foregoing provisions, Robert's Rules of
Order shall govern the deliberations of Council. (Passed 8-1-78.)
121.15  DISRESPECT OR CONTEMPTUOUS CONDUCT TOWARD COUNCIL.
   Council shall have authority to arrest or cause to be arrested and to be
punished by a fine, not in excess of twenty dollars ($20.00), any member or any
other person guilty of disrespect or of contemptuous conduct in its presence
during its sessions, and may cause to be ejected from Council Chambers any
person who, during the session of Council, shall act in an unseemly,
contemptuous or disorderly manner. It shall be the duty of any police or other
officer of the City to carry out the orders of Council made pursuant to this
section. The failure on the part of any person to pay such fine imposed by
Council or to obey its orders as to conduct in its presence, shall constitute a
misdemeanor and shall be punishable as such. (Passed 8-1-78.)
121.16  RENTAL OF CITY BUILDING.
   Portions of the City Building not needed for the use of the City may be
rented  by order of Council. (1972 Code §2-2-9)
121.17  OFFICERS DECLARED AGENTS OF COUNCIL; REPORTS.
   (a)    All officers of the City are hereby declared to be the agents of
Council only, and their acts will be subject to review and approval or
rejection by Council.
   (b)    Every officer of the City shall from time to time as required by law
or ordinance, or when requested by Council, or whenever he shall deem it for
the good of the public service, report to Council in writing respecting the
business of his office or matters connected therewith.  (1972 Code §2-6-1)
121.18  ASSIGNMENT OF ADDITIONAL DUTIES; COMPENSATION.
   Council may, by ordinance or resolution, assign to the officers and
employees duties in respect to the business of any other office or employment,
and such service or duty so assigned shall be rendered without additional
compensation.
(1972 Code §2-6-2)
ARTICLE 123
Ordinances and Resolutions
123.01   Reading; amendment; expenditures.
123.02   Effective date; publication.
123.03   Final vote.
123.04   Endorsement.
123.05   Referenced in Council minutes.
123.06   Preservation and filing of original ordinances; affidavit of
publication.
123.07   Recording of ordinances in "Ordinance Book".
123.08   Indexing of ordinances.
123.09   Destruction of records.
123.10   Service of official notice by police.
123.11   Publication of notices.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Records; ordinance book - see CHTR. §17
Prohibition of oil or smoke ordinances - see CHTR. §22b
To make powers effective - see W. Va. Code 8-11-1
Delegating discretion - see W. Va. Code 8-11-2
Action required to be by ordinance - see W. Va. Code 8-11-3, 8-5-12
Procedures - see W. Va. Code 8-11-4
Penalty limitations - see W. Va. Code 8-12-5(57); 8-11-1
 
 
123.01  READING; AMENDMENT; EXPENDITURES.
   (a)    Every ordinance and every resolution introduced to Council shall be
read in full when introduced and be open to amendment.
   (b)    Every ordinance, and every resolution making or authorizing the
making of any contract involving the expenditure of money to an amount of more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00), shall be complete in the form in which it
is finally passed and remain on file with the Clerk for public inspection for
at least one week before the final passage or adoption thereof. If, after such
ordinance or resolution has been so filed, it is further amended, it must be
again engrossed and remain on file for at least one week before final passage.
(1972 Code §2-4-1)
123.02  EFFECTIVE DATE; PUBLICATION.
   Every ordinance or franchise passed by Council, except where otherwise
provided by general law of the State or by the Charter of the City, shall go
into effect at the expiration of ten days from the time of its final passage;
provided, that within two days after its passage, Sundays and holidays
excepted, such ordinance shall have been published in full in some newspaper
published in and of general circulation in the City; provided further, that an
ordinance for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health or safety,
which shall contain a statement of its urgency, shall become effective at
passage, but such ordinance shall be published as others. (1972 Code §2-4-2)
123.03  FINAL VOTE.
   (a)    Before the final vote is taken upon the passage of any ordinance,
such ordinance shall be read in full, as amended.
   (b)    The vote on all questions as to the consideration and passage of
ordinances or resolutions, and amendments thereto, shall be by "ayes" and
"noes" and shall be entered on the journal. (1972 Code §2-4-3; 2-4-4)
123.04  ENDORSEMENT.
   From the time of its introduction until the time of passage of each
ordinance, the City Clerk shall endorse on the back thereof a memorandum
showing the status of the matter and the various proceedings taken in
connection therewith.
(1972 Code §2-4-5)
123.05  REFERENCED IN COUNCIL MINUTES.
   Before its passage by Council, an ordinance shall be referred to on the
minutes or journal of Council by its title, and after its passage, it shall be
spread verbatim by the Clerk on the minutes of the meeting at which it was
passed.
(1972 Code §2-4-6)
123.06  PRESERVATION AND FILING OF ORIGINAL ORDINANCES;  AFFIDAVIT OF
PUBLICATION.
   The original of every ordinance passed by Council shall be preserved and
filed by the City Clerk in some safe place in his office, properly and plainly
marked and indexed, and with it shall also be filed the affidavit of the
publication of the publisher of the newspaper in which it was printed, showing
its publication. (1972 Code §2-4-7)
123.07  RECORDING OF ORDINANCES IN "ORDINANCE BOOK".
   The City Clerk, within two weeks after any ordinance goes into effect, shall
spread such ordinance verbatim upon a book kept for the purpose and known as
the "Ordinance Book", and to enter at the foot of each ordinance a memorandum
showing the date of its passage by Council. (1972 Code §2-4-8)
123.08  INDEXING OF ORDINANCES.
   The City Clerk shall properly index each ordinance by its appropriate title
in an index annexed to the ordinance book. (1982 Code §2-4-9)
123.09  DESTRUCTION OF RECORDS.
   No person shall destroy, mutilate or secrete the original of any ordinance
passed by Council or any record of such ordinance. (1972 Code §2-4-10)
123.10  SERVICE OF OFFICIAL NOTICES BY POLICE.
   (a)    Any police officer, except where otherwise expressly provided, may
serve, within the City, any notice or process required under any ordinance of
or other law governing the City.
   (b)    The Mayor or the officer whose duty it is to issue any notice shall
direct the same to be served by a police officer.
   (c)    Any police officer to whom any such notice is directed or delivered
to be served, shall immediately execute the same, and make return thereof at
once to the officer issuing it, with his return of service endorsed thereon
showing the manner and time of making such service.
   (d)    No police officer shall receive any additional fee or compensation
for performing such duty. (1972 Code §2-2-2 to 2-2-5)
123.11  PUBLICATION OF NOTICES.
   (a)    All notices or other City matters required to be advertised by any
law of the State or by the Charter or any ordinance of the City, or by
resolution of Council, shall, unless it is otherwise expressly provided, be
published in two newspapers of opposite politics published and of general
circulation in the City.
   (b)    The price to be paid by the City for publication of notices or other
City matters shall not exceed the price fixed for publications by the West
Virginia Code. When required, the publisher shall furnish an affidavit in proof
of the publication without any additional cost to the City.
   (c)    If no newspaper, such as is mentioned in subsection (a) hereof, will
execute such publication at or within the price fixed in subsection (b) hereof,
or if only one such newspaper will so execute it, then such publication shall
be made in one or two other newspapers, as the case may be, published in or of
general circulation in the City, which will make publication at or within the
price fixed by subsection (b) hereof, regardless of the provisions of
subsection (a) hereof.
(1972 Code §2-2-6 to 2-2-8)

131.01  POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Mayor shall be the chief executive officer of the City and the head of
the City government.  He shall take care that all provisions of this Code and
other ordinances, resolutions and orders of the common council are faithfully
executed.  He shall have general supervision and oversight over all
departments, offices and officers of the City.  He shall sign all contracts on
behalf of the City, and shall have the supervision over the preparation and
publication of all statements and reports required by law or ordinance or by
resolution of Council. Notwithstanding any provision of this Codified Ordinance
to the contrary, the Mayor shall have powers to supervise and direct all
offices and employees of the City of St. Marys including, but not limited to,
City Recorder, City Manager and City Attorney and may direct same to provide
reports and other requested information to the Mayor.  He shall faithfully
perform the duties and exercise the powers prescribed for the Mayor by the
Charter; and he shall preside over all meetings of the common council.  The
Mayor shall have such additional powers and perform such additional duties as
may be prescribed for Mayors and other chief executive officers of
municipalities as provided by W.Va. Code, §8-10-01, and as may be prescribed by
this Code and by other ordinances, resolutions and orders of the common
council.  The Mayor shall appoint such assistants and employees as may be
authorized by Council and necessary for the efficient conduct of service to the
City.
(Ord. 2001-12.  Passed 11-20-01.)
131.02  VACANCY.
   If a vacancy occurs in the office of Mayor, a member of Council as
prescribed by  the Charter shall act as Mayor until a Mayor is appointed and
qualified. In such case  Council shall, as soon as practicable, fill the
vacancy by the election of some eligible person who shall hold office during
the balance of the unexpired term.  (1972 Code §2-2-4)
131.03  VOTE.
   The Mayor shall have no vote on any question, except on a tie in Council.
(1972 Code §2-2-5)
131.04  AUTHORITY TO CALL SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   The Mayor shall have the authority to call special meetings of Council as he
may see fit and in the manner provided by law. (1972 Code §2-2-6)
131.05  SUPERVISION OF EMPLOYEES.
   The Mayor shall supervise generally the conduct of all officers and
employees of  the City, examine all reasonable complaints made against any of
them and shall cause  all violations of duty to be promptly reported to
Council. He shall perform such other  duties as may be required by him by the
Charter or by any ordinance of the City.  (1972 Code §2-2-7)
131.06  BOND AND OATH.
   Before entering upon the duties of his office, the Mayor shall give bond as
provided in Section
149.03 and shall take the oath prescribed in Section
149.02. (1972 Code §2-2-8)
131.07  SUSPENSION OF OFFICERS.
   Except as otherwise herein provided, the Mayor shall have authority to
suspend for cause any appointed City officer and to fill the vacancy, if
necessary, until the next meeting of Council. He shall report to Council the
suspension and grounds therefor, for appropriate action.  (1972 Code §2-2-9)
131.08  COMPENSATION.
   The Mayor shall receive compensation for his services as prescribed by the
Charter. (1972 Code §2-2-10)
ARTICLE 133
City Manager
133.01   Appointment; term.
133.02   Oath; bond.
133.03   Duties generally.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Appointment; removal - see CHTR. §6
Powers and duties - see CHTR. §7
Oath; bond - see CHTR. §13
 
 
133.01  APPOINTMENT; TERM.
   The City Manager shall be appointed by Council within a reasonable time
after the general election in the year in which the Mayor and Council are
elected and shall hold office at the pleasure of Council and thereafter until
his successor is appointed and qualified.
(1972 Code §2-8-1)
133.02  OATH; BOND.
   Before entering upon the duties of his office, the City Manager shall take
the oath prescribed by law and shall give bond in the amount of one thousand
dollars ($1,000). Such bond shall be approved by Council conditioned to
faithfully discharge the duties of his office and to faithfully account for and
deliver over all property of the City which may come into his hands or custody,
or under his control by virtue of his office.
(1972 Code §2-8-2)
133.03  DUTIES GENERALLY.
   The City Manager, under the direction of and subject to review and approval
or rejection by Council, shall:
   (a)    Have full charge and authority over all the Municipal affairs of the
City, except those pertaining to the City Recorder, City Collection, Health
Officer, City Attorney and police;
   (b)    Have general supervision over the control, management, construction,
repair and maintenance of the streets, sidewalks and alleys of the City;
   (c)    Have general supervision over the sewerage system of the City;
   (d)    Employ and install such person or persons as are competent and
efficient to do and perform the work under his supervision required for proper
functioning of Municipal government;
   (e)   See that the streets and alleys of the City are kept clean and in a
sanitary condition, and that there shall be no encroachment thereon by abutting
property owners;
   (f)   Prevent anything obnoxious, unsanitary or which is a menace to the
health or comfort of the residents of the City, to be kept or maintained within
the corporate limits of the City, subject to the exceptions contained in the
Charter thereof;
   (g)    Cause all property owners to keep and maintain their properties safe
from fire;
   (h)    Inspect, in conjunction with the police of the City, all buildings at
such times and under such conditions as may be necessary to prevent or remove
fire or health hazards;  (1972 Code §2-8-3)
   (i)    Inspect plans for all proposed building construction in the City,
including proposed subdivisions, and disapprove such as do not comply with the
ordinances and regulations thereof; require that permits be obtained for
building construction; investigate all requests for building permits, and
approve or reject the same; and supervise all building construction to the end
that the same complies with the ordinances and regulations of the City and the
permit granted. (Passed 7-1-75)
   (j)    Direct and authorize, in the interim between meetings of Council, the
issuance of building permits, upon applications therefor duly approved by him;
   (k)    Have immediate control over and responsibility for the proper use,
maintenance and repair of the street sweeping and garbage collection equipment
of the City;
   (l)    Have immediate control over and responsibility for the proper marking
of all streets as to identification thereof, and the regulation and control of
traffic thereon, and the maintenance of such signs;
   (m)    Have immediate responsibility for the construction and maintenance of
proper and safe sidewalks in the City, including inspection thereof, on at
least a semiannual basis and report to Council as to any unsafe or defective
sidewalk with recommendations as to necessary repairs or reconstruction;
   (n)    Have charge of the purchase in bulk and distribution of gasoline and
oils for use in and by the City equipment, and the promulgation and enforcement
of regulations for such distribution;
   (o)    Be responsible, in conjunction with the Chief of Police, for the
collection for deposits made in parking meters, and the accounting for and
delivery of such receipts to the City Recorder;
   (p)    Be responsible for the proper location, marking and development of
all streets and alleys conveyed to or dedicated for use of the City;
   (q)    Approve in writing for payment, before action thereon and payment
thereof by Council, all bills and accounts for materials, supplies and labor
incurred by him, or under his supervision, in behalf of the City; and deliver
the same to the City Recorder;
   (r)    Make such minor purchases of supplies and materials as may be
necessary for the proper maintenance of the Municipal functions under his
supervision, and submit proper statements thereof to Council; 
   (s)    Set up and maintain a supply depot for the City as to materials and
supplies commonly used, provide regulations for the use thereof, furnish to
Council  inventories of materials and supplies on hand at least annually, and
from time to  time provide Council with requisitions or lists of supplies and
materials  necessary to be purchased, so that purchase in wholesale quantities
or at  discount may be had and made;
   (t)    Perform all such other general or special duties as from time to time
may be required by Council. (1972 Code §2-8-3)
   (u)    Inspect plans for all proposed subdivisions to insure the harmonious
development of the Municipality and its environs; to insure that the land is
suitable for  building sites; to insure coordination of roads with the
subdivided land with other existing or planned roads or with the State or
Municipality planned roads; to insure that the adequate rights of way for
future streets are preserved; to insure protection of natural drainage
channels; to insure that water and sewer service are adequate; to insure that
needed site improvements are  made; to insure that scattered or premature
subdivision of land is avoided as would involve danger of injury to health,
safety or property by reason of the lack of water supply, drainage,
transportation or other public services, or would  necessitate an excessive
expenditure of public funds to supply such services; and to prevent excessive
governmental operating cost; and to approve or disapprove  such plans.  (Passed
7-1-75.)
ARTICLE 135
City Recorder
135.01   Appointment; term.
135.02   Oath; bond.
135.03   Duties generally.
135.04   Duties as City Collector.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Appointment; removal - see CHTR. §6
Powers and duties - see CHTR. §7

Records - see CHTR. §17
Position established - see W. Va. Code 8-5-7
