assistance programs.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Composition; organization - see W. Va. Code 8-24-4 et seq.
Powers and duties - see W. Va. Code 8-24-14 et seq.
Approval of subdivision plats - see W. Va. Code 8-24-28 et seq.
 
 
1301.01  AUTHORIZATION.
   In order to promote the orderly development of the community, a municipal
planning commission, hereafter known as the St. Marys Planning Commission is
hereby established. The Commission shall have the authority to advise and make
recommendations to Council, but such recommendations shall not be binding.
(Passed 10-20-81.)
1301.02  OBJECTIVES.
   The general objectives of the Planning Commission shall be that highway
systems be carefully planned; that new community centers grow only with
adequate highway, utility, health, educational and recreational facilities;
that the needs of agriculture, industry and business be recognized in future
growth; that residential areas provide healthy surroundings for family life;
and that the growth of the community be commensurate with and promotive of the
efficient and economical use of public funds. (Passed 10-20-81.)
1301.03  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this article:
   (a)    "Planning Commission" or "Commission" means the municipal planning
commission of the City of St. Marys;
   (b)    "Comprehensive Plan" may mean a complete comprehensive plan or any of
its parts such as a comprehensive plan of land use and zoning of thoroughfares,
of sanitation, of recreation, and of other related matters. It may include such
ordinance or ordinances as may be deemed necessary to implement such complete
comprehensive plan;
   (c)    "Public place" includes any tracts owned by the City;
   (d)    "Streets" includes streets, avenues, boulevards, highways, roads,
lanes, alleys and all public ways;
   (e)    "Unit of government" means any federal, State, regional, county or
municipal government;
   (f)    "Utility" means any facility used in rendering service which the
public has a right to demand; and
   (g)    "Governing body" means the common Council of the City of St. Marys.
      (Passed 10-20-81.)
1301.04  MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT; TERM.
   (a)    The Planning Commission shall consist of seven qualified voters all
of whom shall be at least three year residents of the City. They shall be
qualified by knowledge and experience in matters pertaining to the development
of the City. They shall include representatives of business, industry and
labor, and shall be nominated by the Mayor, subject to the confirmation of
Council. One member of the Commission shall also be a member of Council of the
City and another member shall also be a member of the administrative branch of
the City. The term of these two members shall be co-extensive with the term of
office to which they have been selected or appointed. Council and the Mayor,
however, may designate others to serve as the City's representatives on the
Commission, so long as such designation occurs at the first regular meeting of
the Commission each year.
   (b)    The initial appointment of the remaining members of the Commission
shall be in the following manner: one member shall be appointed to a one year
term; two members shall each be appointed to two year terms; and two members
shall each be appointed to three year terms. Thereafter, members shall be
selected for terms of three years each. Vacancies shall be filled for the
unexpired term only, in the same manner as original selections are made.
Members of the Commission shall serve at compensation to be determined by the
governing body and shall be reimbursed for all necessary expenses incurred in
the performance of their official duties . (Passed 10-20-81.)
1301.05  REGULAR AND SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   (a)    The Planning Commission shall hold regular meetings on the second
Tuesday of each month.
   (b)    Special meetings of the Commission may be called by the chairman or
by at least two members, upon submission of a written request to the secretary.
The secretary shall send to all members at least forty-eight hours in advance
of a special meeting a written notice fixing the date, time, place and purpose
of the meeting.
(Passed 10-20-81.)
1301.06  QUORUM.
   A majority of the members of the Planning Commission shall constitute a
quorum. However, no action of the commission shall be official unless
authorized by a two-thirds vote of all the members of the Commission at a
regular or properly called special meeting.
(Passed 10-20-81.)
1301.07  APPROPRIATION OF EXPENSES.
   (a)    Council shall provide the Planning Commission with suitable offices
for the holding of meetings and the preservation of plans, maps, documents and
accounts, and shall provide by appropriation a sum sufficient to defray the
necessary expenses of the Commission.
   (b)    All expenditures in excess of fifty dollars ($50.00) must be approved
by Council. All expenditures less than fifty dollars ($50.00) are to be
approved by the City Manager. (Passed 10-20-81.)
1301.08  ELECTION OF OFFICERS.
   At the first regular meeting of each year, the Planning Commission shall
elect from its membership a chairperson and vice-chairperson. Neither of these
persons shall be the representative of Council nor the administrative branch of
the City. The vice-chairperson shall have the powers and responsibilities of
the chairperson during his absence.
(Passed 10-20-81.)
1301.09  ADMINISTRATIVE POWERS AND AUTHORITY.
   To effectuate the purposes of this article, the Planning Commission shall
have the power, authority and duty to:
   (a)    Exercise general supervision of and make rules and regulations for
the administration of the affairs of the Commission;
   (b)    Prescribe uniform rules and regulations pertaining to its
investigations and hearings;
   (c)    Supervise the fiscal affairs and responsibilities of the Commission;
   (d)    Prescribe the qualification of, appoint, remove and fix the
compensation of the employees of the Commission. Such compensation is to be in
conformity to and in compliance with the salaries and compensation fixed by
Council;
   (e)    Delegate to employees authority to perform ministerial acts in all
cases, except where the final action of the Commission is necessary;
   (f)    Keep an accurate and complete record of all departmental proceedings,
and records and file all bonds and contracts and assume responsibility for the
custody and preservation of all papers and documents of the Commission;
   (g)    Make recommendations and an annual report to Council concerning the
operation of the Commission and the status of planning within its jurisdiction;
   (h)    Prepare, publish, and distribute reports, ordinances, and other
material relating to the activities authorized under this article;
   (i)    Prepare and submit an annual budget in the same manner as other
Municipal departments. The Commission shall be limited in all expenditures to
the provisions made therefore by Council;
   (j)    If deemed necessary, establish an advisory committee or committees;
and
   (k)    Delegate to a committee composed of one or more members of the
Commission, the power to hold any public hearings or conferences required or
permitted under this article to be held by the Commission. If the hearing or
conference is held by a committee, a written record of the substance of the
hearing or conference shall be made and preserved with the records of the
Commission for not less than five years. The committee shall have authority
only to conduct the hearing and report to the Commission.
      (Passed 10-20-81.)
1301.10  EXPENDITURES; DISPOSITION OF GIFTS; PARTICIPATION IN FEDERAL PLANNING
ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS.
   (a)    The Planning Commission shall have the power and authority to expend,
under regular Municipal procedure as established in Section
1301.07 and elsewhere, all sums appropriated to it for the purposes and
activities authorized under this article.
   (b)    The Municipality may accept gifts or donations for Planning
Commission purposes. Any moneys accepted shall be deposited with the City in a
special nonreverting Planning Commission fund to be available for expenditures
for the purpose designated by the donor. The Municipal Recorder shall draw
warrants against such funds only upon vouchers signed by the chairman and
secretary of the Commission.
   (c)    The Planning Commission is empowered and authorized to accept, spend
and use funds provided for the purposes of this article by the government of
the United States and any other agency or group whose interests are in harmony
with such purposes, in accordance with federal requirements and subject to such
conditions or limitations as the Constitution or law of this State may provide.
(Passed 10-20-81.)
ARTICLE 1305
Comprehensive Plan
1305.01   Plan required prior to development.
1305.02   Contents.
1305.03   Notice and public hearing.
1305.04   Adoption by Planning  Commission.
1305.05   Certification and presentment  to Council.
1305.06   Consideration of plan and  ordinance by Council; publication.
1305.07   Rejection or amendment by Council.
1305.08   Amendment of plan and ordinance after adoption.
1305.09   Validation of prior action.
1305.10   Interdepartmental cooperation.
1305.11   Jurisdiction of Planning Commission.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Preparation - see W. Va. Code 8-24-16
Defined - see P.& Z.
1301.03(b)
 
 
1305.01  PLAN REQUIRED PRIOR TO DEVELOPMENT.
   The Planning Commission shall make and recommend for adoption to the
governing body a comprehensive plan for the physical development of the
territory within the corporate limits of the City. In preparing a comprehensive
plan, the Planning Commission shall make careful and comprehensive surveys and
studies of the existing conditions and probable future changes of such
conditions within the corporate limits of the City.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1305.02  CONTENTS.
   The comprehensive plan may include the following or a study of the
following:
   (a)    Careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of existing conditions
and the probable future growth of the Municipality.
   (b)    Maps, plats, charts and descriptive material presenting basic
information, locations, extent and character of any of the following:
      (1)    History, population and physical site conditions;
      (2)    Land use, including the height, area, bulk, locations; and use of
private and public structures and premises;
      (3)    Population densities;
      (4)    Community centers and neighborhood units;
      (5)    Blighted and slum areas;
      (6)    Streets, including bridges, viaducts, parkways, and other public
ways  and places;
      (7)    Sewers, sanitation and drainage, including handling, treatment and
disposal of excess drainage waters, sewage, garbage, refuse, wastes, ashes,
trash and other similar matters;
      (8)    Stream pollution;
      (9)    Flood control and prevention;
      (10)    Public and private utilities, including water, light, heat,
communication and other services;
      (11)    Transportation, including rail, bus, truck, air and water
transport and their terminal facilities;
      (12)    Local mass transportation, including busses; street, elevated or
underground railways and taxicabs;
      (13)    Parks and recreation, including parks, playgrounds, reservations,
forests, public grounds, and spaces and facilities of a recreational nature;
      (14)    Public buildings and institutions, including governmental
administration and service buildings, hospitals, infirmaries, clinics, penal
and correctional institutions and other civic and social service buildings;
      (15)    Education, including location and extent of schools;
      (16)    Land utilization, including residence, industry, agriculture,
forests and other uses;
      (17)    Conservation of water, soil, agricultural and mineral resources;
and
      (18)    Any other factors which are a part of the physical, economic, or
social situation within the City.
   (c)    Reports, maps, charts and recommendations setting forth plans for the
development, redevelopment, improvement, extension and revision of the subjects
set out in subsection (b) hereof so as to substantially accomplish the
objective set forth in Section
1301.02.
   (d)    A long-range development program of public works projects, based on
the recommended plans of the Commission, for the purpose of eliminating
unplanned, unsightly, untimely and extravagant projects and with a view to
stabilizing industry and employment, and the keeping of such program up to date
by yearly revisions.
   (e)    A long-range financial program of governmental expenditures in order
that such development program may be carried out, and the keeping of such
program up to date, for all separate taxing units within the City for the
purpose of assuring efficient and economic use of public funds.
      (Passed 3-20-79.)
1305.03  NOTICE AND PUBLIC HEARING.
   Prior to the adoption of the comprehensive plan the Planning Commission
shall hold a public hearing and give at least thirty days notice prior to the
date set for the hearings. The notice shall contain the date, time, and place
of the hearings and it shall be published as Class I Legal Advertisements in
compliance with the provisions of Chapter W. Va. 59-3-1. The area for such
notice shall be the Municipality. (Passed 3-20-79.)
1305.04  ADOPTION BY PLANNING COMMISSION.
   After a public hearing has been held, the Planning Commission may, by
resolution, adopt the comprehensive plan and recommend the ordinance to
Council.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1305.05  CERTIFICATION AND PRESENTMENT TO COUNCIL.
   (a)    Upon adoption of the comprehensive plan, and recommendation of the
ordinance by the Planning Commission, the secretary shall certify a copy of the
plan to Council.
   (b)    At the first meeting of Council after adoption of the plan, the
secretary or a member of the Commission shall present the plan to Council.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1305.06  CONSIDERATION OF PLAN AND ORDINANCE BY COUNCIL;  PUBLICATION.
   After presentation of the plan to Council, Council shall proceed to a
consideration of the plan and ordinance and shall either adopt, reject or amend
the plan. If the ordinance adopting the comprehensive plan is published, the
plan may be incorporated by reference in the ordinance and the full text of the
plan need not be published.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1305.07  REJECTION OR AMENDMENT BY COUNCIL.
   (a)    If Council rejects the plan and ordinance, or amends it, then it
shall be returned to the Planning Commission, along with a written explanation
of the reasons for its rejection or amendment.
   (b)    The Planning Commission shall have forty-five days in which to
consider the rejection or amendment and report back to Council. If the
Commission approves the amendment, the ordinance shall stand as adopted by
Council. If the Commission disapproves of the rejection or amendment, it shall
state its reasons for such disapproval in the report, and Council shall again
consider the plan and ordinance, and its action in rejecting or amending the
plan and ordinance, after such consideration, shall be final.
   (c)    In case the Commission does not file a report with Council within
forty-five days, the action in rejecting or amending the plan and ordinance
shall be final.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1305.08  AMENDMENT OF PLAN AND ORDINANCE AFTER ADOPTION.
   After the adoption of the comprehensive plan and ordinance, all amendments
to it shall be adopted according to the procedures set forth in Sections
1305.03 through
1305.07, except that publication of the notices of the date, time and place of
the hearings upon such amendment need only be fifteen or more days prior to the
hearing. If the governing body desires an amendment, it may direct the Planning
Commission to prepare an amendment and submit it to public hearings within
sixty days after formal written request by Council.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1305.09  VALIDATION OF PRIOR ACTION.
   The adoption of a comprehensive plan or any general development plans by the
Planning Commission under the authority of prior acts is hereby validated and
shall continue in effect until amended under authority of this article. (Passed
3-20-79.)
1305.10  INTERDEPARTMENTAL COOPERATION.
   Whenever the Planning Commission undertakes the preparation of a
comprehensive plan, the various Municipal officials and departments shall make
available upon the request of the Commission, such information as relates to
the Commission's activity.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1305.11  JURISDICTION OF PLANNING COMMISSION.
   The authority of the Planning Commission shall not extend beyond the
corporate limits of the City. (Passed 3-20-79.)
CHAPTER THREE - Subdivision Control
Art.
1311. Subdivision Plats.
ARTICLE 1311
Subdivision Plats
1311.01   Approval required prior to recordation.
1311.02   Application for approval; notice and hearing.
1311.03   Basis for Commission's action  upon application.
1311.04   Effect of approval or disapproval.
1311.05   Applications fees.
1311.06   Plats filed without approval.
1311.07   Conditional approval; bonds.
1311.08   Improvement location permits; authority to issue and control.
1311.09   Appeals.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Subdivision regulations - see W. Va. Code 8-24-28 et seq.
Conditional approval of subdivision - see W. Va. Code 8-24-34
 
 
1311.01  APPROVAL REQUIRED PRIOR TO RECORDATION.
   After a comprehensive plan and an ordinance, containing provisions for
subdivision control and the approval of plats and replats has been adopted by
Council and a certified copy of the ordinance has been filed with the clerk of
the County Clerk of the Pleasants County Commission a plat of a subdivision
must be approved by the Planning Commission before it can be recorded. (Passed
3-20-79.)
1311.02  APPLICATION FOR APPROVAL; NOTICE AND HEARING.
   (a)    A person desiring the approval of a plat shall submit a written
application for approval, together with a copy of the proposed plat, to the
Planning Commission.
   (b)    Upon receipt of the application, the Planning Commission, if it
tentatively approves the application shall set a date, time and place for a
hearing, notify the applicant in writing, and notify by publication in the
manner specified in Section
1305.03.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1311.03  BASIS FOR COMMISSION'S ACTION UPON APPLICATION.
   (a)    In determining whether an application for approval shall be granted,
the Planning Commission shall determine if the plat provides for:
      (1)    Coordination of subdivision streets with existing and planned
streets;
      (2)    Coordination with and extension of facilities included in the
comprehensive plan;
      (3)    Establishment of minimum width, depth and area of lots within the
projected subdivision;
      (4)    Distribution of population and traffic in a manner tending to
create conditions favorable to health, safety, convenience and the harmonious
development of the City; and
      (5)    Fair allocations of areas for streets, parks, schools, public and
semipublic buildings, homes, utilities, business and industry.
   (b)    As a condition of approval of a plat, the Commission may specify:
      (1)    The manner in which streets and sidewalks shall be laid out,
graded and improved;
      (2)    Provisions for water, sewage and other utility services;
      (3)    Provisions for schools;
      (4)    Provisions for essential Municipal services;
      (5)    Provisions for recreational facilities.
         (Passed 3-20-79.)
1311.04  EFFECT OF APPROVAL OR DISAPPROVAL.
   Following the hearing, the Planning Commission shall either approve or
disapprove the application for approval of the plat. If the Commission approves
the application, it shall affix the Commission's seal upon the plat. If it
disapproves the application, it shall set forth its own records and provide the
applicant with a copy thereof. The applicant may re-submit his plat for
approval, provided he alleviates the reasons given for its original
disapproval.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1311.05  APPLICATIONS FEES.
   The Planning Commission shall charge a fee of $           for all
applications for approval of plats. (Passed 3-20-79.)
1311.06  PLATS FILED WITHOUT APPROVAL.
   The filing and recording of a plat involving the subdivision of lands
covered by the comprehensive plan and ordinance shall be without legal effect
unless approved by the Planning Commission; provided that failure to comply
with this section shall not invalidate or affect the title to any land within
the area of such plat.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1311.07  CONDITIONAL APPROVAL; BONDS.
   (a)    The Planning Commission may approve a plat for a subdivision in which
the improvements and installations have not been completed as required if the
applicant provides a bond which shall:
      (1)    Run to the City;
      (2)    Be in an amount determined by the Commission to be sufficient to
complete the improvements and installations;
      (3)    Be with surety satisfactory to the Planning Commission;
      (4)    Specify the time for the completion of the improvements and
installations.
   (b)    If the applicant fails to complete the improvements and
installations, the City may carry out such improvements and installations.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1311.08  IMPROVEMENT LOCATION PERMITS; AUTHORITY TO  ISSUE AND CONTROL.
   (a)    An improvement location permit for a structure of platted or
unplatted lands shall not be issued unless the structure and its location
conform to this City's comprehensive plan and ordinance.
   (b)    The Building Inspector shall have the authority to issue and control
improvement location permits within this City.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1311.09  APPEALS.
   A decision of the Planning Commission may be reviewed by a writ of
certiorari in a court of competent jurisdiction. A petition for certiorari
shall specify the grounds upon which it is alleged that the Commission's action
is illegal or improper. Such petition must be filed within sixty days following
the Commission's decision.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
CHAPTER FIVE - Zoning Regulations

ARTICLE 1321
Authority
1321.01   Zoning authority.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Zoning authority generally - see W. Va. Code 8-24-39
Enforcement provisions - see W. Va. Code 8-24-66 et seq.
 
 
1321.01  ZONING AUTHORITY.
   In order to obtain the objectives of this Chapter, Council shall have and
exercise the following powers:
   (a)    To classify, regulate and limit the height, area, bulk and use of
buildings hereafter to be erected;
   (b)    To regulate and determine the area of front, rear and side yards,
courts and other open spaces about such buildings;
   (c)    To regulate and determine the use and intensity of use of land and
lot areas;
   (d)    To classify, regulate and restrict the location of trades; callings,
industries, commercial enterprises and the location of buildings designed for
specified uses;
   (e)    To regulate and control, or prohibit in certain areas, junk yards,
dumps or automobile or appliance grave yards, or the maintenance and operation
of second hand stores or outlets in residential areas;
   (f)    To classify and designate the rural lands among agricultural,
industrial, commercial, residential and other uses and purposes;
   (g)    To divide the Municipality into districts of such kind, character,
number, shape and area as may be necessary to carry out the purposes of this
section.
      (Passed 3-20-79.)
ARTICLE 1325
Districts
1325.01   Zoning district generally.
1325.02   Preliminary study.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Zoning districts generally - see W. Va. Code 8-24-40
Nonconforming uses - see P.& Z. Art.
1341
 
 
1325.01  ZONING DISTRICTS GENERALLY.
   The various kinds of districts created in order to carry out the purposes of
this Chapter, need not necessarily cover or include the same territory, and may
overlap or coincide. The districts created shall also be subject to the
following:
   (a)    Rules and regulations as to height, area, bulk, and use of buildings
and as to the area of all yards, courts and open spaces shall be uniform for
each class of buildings throughout each district;
   (b)    For each district designated for the location of trades, callings,
industries, commercial enterprises or buildings, designated for specified uses,
rules and regulations may be enforced specifying uses that shall be excluded or
subjected to reasonable requirements of a special nature and designating the
use for which buildings may not be erected, altered or used;
   (c)    The rules and regulations in one or more districts of the same kind
or character may differ from those in other like districts but shall be uniform
for each district; and
   (d)    Several parts of the Municipality may be classified within a single
district although not contiguous.
      (Passed 3-20-79.)
1325.02  PRELIMINARY STUDY.
   In establishing such districts and rules and regulations, Council shall give
reasonable regard to existing conditions, the character of buildings erected in
each district, the most desirable use for which the land in each district may
be adapted and the conservation of property values throughout the City.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
ARTICLE 1329
Procedures
1329.01   Tentative report; notice  and hearings.
1329.02   Action by governing body on tentative report.
1329.03   Final report; notice and hearing; action.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Amendments - see P.& Z. Art.
1333
Appeals - see P.& Z.
1345.06
 
 
1329.01  TENTATIVE REPORT; NOTICE AND HEARINGS.
   (a)    Recommendations as to the boundaries of districts and rules and
regulations and restrictions to be enforced shall be prepared by the Planning
Commission. The Commission may prepare the tentative report on its own
initiative or Council may require its preparation.
   (b)    The Commission shall hold preliminary hearings and conferences, on
such dates at such times and places and upon such notice as it may determine to
be necessary to inform and aid itself in the preparation of the tentative
report.
   (c)    The tentative report, which shall include the proposed zoning
ordinance with explanatory maps, shall be made to Council by the secretary of
the Commission.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1329.02  ACTION BY GOVERNING BODY ON TENTATIVE REPORT.
   (a)    Council shall consider the tentative report and shall return it, with
any suggestions and recommendations, to the Planning Commission for its final
report.
   (b)    Until the final report of the Commission is received by Council, no
zoning ordinance shall be adopted. (Passed 3-20-79.)
1329.03  FINAL REPORT; NOTICE AND HEARING; ACTION.
   After the Planning Commission submits the final report, Council shall give
all interested persons an opportunity to be heard, with reference to the final
report, at public hearings convenient for all persons affected. Notices of the
dates, times and places of such hearings shall be published as Class II legal
advertisements within fourteen consecutive days preceding the date set for the
hearings. The notices shall state that the report contains a comprehensive
zoning ordinance for the City, that written objection to the final report,
filed with the City Recorder at or before the hearings, will be heard and that
the hearings will be continued from time to time as may be found necessary.
During the time between the date of the first publication of the notice and the
date of the hearing, the final report shall be on file in the office of the
Planning Commission, available for public inspection. Upon completion of the
public hearings, Council shall proceed to the consideration of the ordinance.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
ARTICLE 1333
Amendments; Supplements; Changes
1333.01   By Council.
1333.02   Petition for change of rules  and regulations.
1333.03   Changes of zoning rules and regulations.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Amendments - see W. Va. Code 8-24-45 et seq.
Board of Zoning Appeals - see P. & Z. Art.
1345
 
 
1333.01  BY COUNCIL.
   Council may, from time to time, amend, supplement or change the rules and
regulations and districts fixed by the Zoning Ordinance.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1333.02  PETITION FOR CHANGE OF RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   Petitions, duly signed, may be presented to the City Recorder requesting an
amendment, supplement of or a change in the rules and regulations of zoning
ordinance by:
   (a)    The Planning Commission;
   (b)    The owners of fifty percent (50%) or more of the real property area
to which the petition relates.
      (Passed 3-20-79.)
1333.03  CHANGES OF ZONING RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   (a)    Amendments, supplements or changes of the rules and regulations, of
the Zoning Ordinance shall be considered as amendments to the comprehensive
plan. Any proposed ordinance for the amendment, supplement, change or repeal of
the Zoning Ordinance, not originating upon petition of the Planning Commission,
shall be referred to the Commission for consideration and report before any
final action is taken by Council.
   (b)    Prior to submission to Council of a Planning Commission petition or a
report on a proposed ordinance referred to it for amendment, supplement, change
or repeal of the Zoning Ordinance, the Commission shall give notices and hold
public hearings in the manner prescribed under Section
1305.03, except that publication need be made only fifteen or more days prior
to the date set for such hearings.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
ARTICLE 1337
Elections
1337.01   Submission to voters; petition.
1337.02   Ballots; ballot labels.
1337.03   Designation of election.
1337.04   Notice.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Petition for change of rules and regulations - see P.& Z.
1333.02
 
 
1337.01  SUBMISSION TO VOTERS; PETITION.
   If, within sixty days following adoption of the Zoning Ordinance by Council,
a petition is filed with the City Recorder asking for submission of the Zoning
Ordinance to the qualified voters of the City, such ordinance shall not take
effect until the ordinance has been approved by a majority of the legal votes
cast at any regular primary or general or special election called for that
purpose. The petition must be signed by a number of qualified voters, in their
own handwriting, residing in the area affected by the proposed zoning equal to
not less then fifteen percent (15%) of the total legal votes cast in the
affected area for all candidates for governor at the last preceding general
election at which a governor was elected. Only qualified voters residing in the
area affected by the proposed ordinance shall be eligible to vote with respect
thereto. (Passed 3-20-79.)
1337.02  BALLOTS; BALLOT LABELS.
   (a)    Upon the ballots, or ballot labels where voting machines are used
there shall be written or printed the following:
         
         For Zoning
         Against Zoning
   (b)    If a majority of the legal votes cast upon the question be for
zoning, the provisions of the Zoning Ordinance shall, upon the date the results
of such an election are declared, be effective. If a majority of the legal
votes cast upon the question be against zoning, such Zoning Ordinance shall not
take effect, but the question may again be submitted to a vote at any regular
primary or general election in the manner herein provided .
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1337.03  DESIGNATION OF ELECTION.
   Council, shall designate whether such election shall be held as a primary,
general or special election. The election at which the question of zoning is
voted upon shall be held at the voting precincts established for holding
primary or general elections. All of the provisions of the general election
laws of this State concerning primary, general or special elections, when not
in conflict with the provisions of this chapter, shall apply to voting. and
elections hereunder, insofar as practicable.  (Passed 3-20-79.)
1337.04  NOTICE.
   Notice of all elections at which the question of zoning is voted upon shall
be given by publication of the order calling for a vote on such question as a
Class II legal advertisement. The publication area for such publication shall
be the area in which voting on the question of zoning is to be conducted.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
ARTICLE 1341
Nonconforming Uses
1341.01   Existing uses safeguarded.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Existing uses safeguarded - see W. Va. Code 8-24-50
 
 
1341.01  EXISTING USES SAFEGUARDED.
   The Zoning Ordinance shall not prohibit the continuance of the use of any
land, building or structure for the purpose for which such land, building or
structure is used at the time the Zoning Ordinance takes effect, but any
alteration or addition to any land, building or structure for the purpose of
carrying on any use prohibited under the zoning rules and regulations
applicable to the district may be prohibited, provided, that no such
prohibition shall apply to alterations or additions to or replacement of
buildings or structures by any farmer, industry, or manufacturer, or to the use
of land presently owned by any farmer, industry or manufacturer but not used
for agricultural, industrial or manufacturing purposes, or to the use or
acquisition of additional land which may be required for the protection,
continuing development or expansion of any agricultural, industrial or
manufacturing operation or any present or future satellite agricultural,
industrial or manufacturing use.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
ARTICLE 1345
Board of Zoning Appeals
1345.01   Creation; membership; terms; vacancies.
1345.02   Officers; quorum; compensation  of secretary and employees.
1345.03   Offices; appropriation for expenses.
1345.04   Rules, regulations, procedures; minutes and records.
1345.05   Powers, authority and duties.
1345.06   Hearing of appeal.
1345.07   Staying of work on premises when appeal taken; exception.
1345.08   Petition for writ of certiorari decision or order.
   
CROSS REFERENCES
Board of Zoning Appeals - see W. Va. Code 8-24-51 et seq.
Amendments - see P.& Z. Art.
1333
 
 
1345.01  CREATION; MEMBERSHIP; TERMS; VACANCIES.
   (a)    As part of the Zoning Ordinance, Council hereby establishes the Board
of Zoning Appeals, consisting of five members to be appointed by Council.
   (b)    The members of the Board of Zoning Appeals shall be individuals who
are freeholders and residents of the City and at least three-fifths of such
members shall have been residents of the City for at least ten years preceding
the time of their appointment. No member of the Board of Zoning Appeals shall
be a member of the Planning Commission nor shall any member hold other elective
or appointive offices in the City government, nor shall more than one
particular interest or profession be represented.
   (c)    Members of the Board shall serve without compensation, but shall be
reimbursed for all reasonable and necessary expenses incurred in the
performance of their duties.
   (d)    Upon initial creation of the Board of Zoning Appeals, the members
shall be appointed for the following terms: One for a term of one year; two for
a term of two years; and two for a term of three years. The terms shall expire
on the first day of January of the first, second, and third year, respectively,
following their appointment. Thereafter, as their terms expire, each new
appointment shall be for a term of three years.
   (e)    If a vacancy occurs on the Board of Zoning Appeals, Council shall
appoint a new member, for the length of the unexpired term.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1345.02  OFFICERS; QUORUM; COMPENSATION OF SECRETARY AND EMPLOYEES.
   (a)    At its first meeting of each year, the Board of Zoning Appeals shall
elect a chairman and vice-chairman from its membership. The vice-chairman shall
have the power and authority to act as chairman whenever the chairman is unable
to discharge the duties of his office.
   (b)    A majority of the members of the Board of Zoning Appeals shall
constitute a quorum. No action of the Board shall be official, unless
authorized by a majority of its members.
   (c)    The Board of Zoning Appeals may appoint and fix the compensation of a
secretary and such employees as are necessary for the discharge of its duties,
all in conformity to and in compliance with the rates of compensation set by
Council.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1345.03  OFFICES; APPROPRIATION FOR EXPENSES.
   Council shall provide the Board of Zoning Appeals with suitable offices and
shall appropriate enough money to sufficiently defray the reasonable expense of
the Board.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1345.04  RULES, REGULATIONS, PROCEDURES; MINUTES AND RECORDS.
   (a)    The Board of Zoning Appeals shall adopt such rules and regulations
concerning the filing of appeals, applications for vacancies and exceptions,
the giving of notice and the conduct of hearings as may be necessary to carry
out its duties under the terms of this article.
   (b)    The Board shall keep minutes of its proceedings, keep records of all
official actions and shall record the vote on all actions taken. All minutes
and records shall be filed in the office of the Board and shall be public
record.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1345.05  POWERS, AUTHORITY AND DUTIES.
   (a)    The Board of Zoning Appeals shall:
      (1)    Hear and determine appeals from and review any order, requirement,
decision or determination made by an administrative official or board charged
with the enforcement of any ordinance or rule and regulation adopted pursuant
to this Chapter.
      (2)    Permit and authorize exceptions to the district rules and
regulations only in the classes of cases or in a particular situation, as
specified in the Zoning Ordinance;
      (3)    Hear and decide special exceptions to the terms required to act
under the ordinance;
      (4)   Authorize upon appeal in specific cases such variance from the
terms of the Zoning Ordinance as will not be contrary to the public interest,
where, owing to special condition, a literal enforcement of the provisions of
the Zoning Ordinance will result in undue hardship, and so that the spirit of
the Zoning Ordinance shall be observed and substantial justice done.
   (b)    In exercising its powers and authority, the Board may reserve or
affirm, in whole or in part, or may modify the order, requirement, decision or
determination appealed from. To this end, the Board shall have all the powers
and authority of the administrative official or board from whom the appeal is
taken.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1345.06  HEARING OF APPEAL.
   The Board of Zoning Appeals shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of
an appeal. Public notice of the hearing shall be given in the manner specified
in Section
1305.03. Notice shall also be given, by registered mail to all persons who own
property within a three block radius of the affected area and a sign shall be
posted on the affected premises, indicating the date, time, and place of the
hearing.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1345.07  STAYING OF WORK ON PREMISES WHEN APPEAL TAKEN;  EXCEPTION.
   When an appeal has been taken and filed with the Board of Zoning Appeals,
all proceedings and work on the premises in question shall be stayed unless the
administrative official or Board from whom or which the appeal is taken shall
certify that by reason of facts stated in the certificate a stay would cause
imminent peril of life or property. If such certificate be filed, proceedings
or work on the premises shall not be stayed except by a restraining order
granted by a court of competent jurisdiction.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1345.08  PETITION FOR WRIT OF CERTIORARI FROM DECISION  OR ORDER.
   (a)    Every decision or order of the Board of Zoning Appeals shall be
subject to review by certiorari in a court of competent jurisdiction. The
provisions of Section
1311.09 shall also apply in this section.
   (b)    Upon review of certiorari all proceedings and work on the premises in
question shall be stayed unless the administrative official or board from whom
or which the appeal is taken shall certify that a stay would cause imminent
peril to life or property.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
ARTICLE 1349
Enforcement and Penalty
1349.01   Enforcement.
1349.02   Injunction.
1349.03   Conflicts of law.
1349.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Enforcement - see W. Va. Code 8-24-66 et seq.
Appeals - see P.& Z. Art.
1345
 
 
1349.01  ENFORCEMENT.
   Council shall provide penalties, as set out in Section
1349.99, for failure to comply with the provisions of any ordinance or rule and
regulation adopted pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. Any buildings
erected, raised, or converted on land or premises used in violation of any
provisions of any ordinance or rule and regulation adopted under the authority
of this chapter shall be considered a common nuisance. The owner of such
building, land or premises shall be liable for maintaining a common nuisance.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1349.02  INJUNCTION.
   The Planning Commission, the Board of Zoning Appeals or any designated
official may seek an injunction in a court of competent jurisdiction to
restrain a person or unit of government from violating the provisions of this
chapter or of any ordinance or rule and regulation adopted pursuant hereto. The
Planning Commission, the Board of Zoning Appeals or any designated enforcement
official such as the Building Inspector may also seek a mandatory injunction in
a court of competent jurisdiction directing a person or unit of government to
remove a structure erected in violation of the provisions of this chapter or of
any ordinance or rule and regulation adopted pursuant hereto. If the Planning
Commission, the Board of Zoning Appeals or the designated enforcement official
is successful in any such suit, the respondent shall bear the costs of the
action.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1349.03  CONFLICTS OF LAW.
   Whenever any provision of this chapter conflicts with the provisions of any
other ordinance, or statute, the provisions which establish a higher standard
shall prevail.
(Passed 3-20-79.)
1349.99  PENALTY. 
   Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor and upon conviction, shall be fined not less than ten dollars
($10.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00).
CODIFIED ORDINANCES OF ST. MARYS
PART FIFTEEN - FIRE PREVENTION CODE
Art.
1505.  General Provisions.
Art.
1509.  Outdoor Fires.
ARTICLE 1505
General Provisions
1505.01   Obedience to orders at fires.
1505.02   Smoking restricted.
1505.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority of fire departments - see W. Va. Code Art. 29-3A
Directing traffic at scene of fire - see TRAF.
303.01
Obstructing officer - see GEN. OFF.
501.02
False alarms - see GEN. OFF.
501.03
 
 
1505.01  OBEDIENCE TO ORDERS AT FIRES.
   Whoever shall be present at a fire shall be subject and obedient to the
orders of the Chief of the Fire Department, or to the orders of any fireman or
police officer in any matter relating to the extinguishing of fire and the
removal and protection of property.  Whoever neglects or refuses to obey such
orders shall be guilty of a violation of this section. All officers shall have
the power to arrest any person so neglecting or refusing to obey any such
lawful orders, to hold him in custody until after the fire shall have been
extinguished and then any such person guilty of such violation shall be taken
before the Municipal Court Judge of the City to be dealt with according to law.
1505.02  SMOKING  RESTRICTED.
   (a)    No person shall smoke or carry a lighted cigarette, cigar or pipe in
any public place where the City Manager has placed a "Smoking Prohibited" sign.
   (b)    The City Manager shall conspicuously display a sign reading "Smoking
Prohibited" in those places where smoking is prohibited.
   (c)    No person shall remove, deface or destroy any "No Smoking" sign
posted pursuant to the provisions of this section.
1505.99  PENALTY. 
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
101.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.) 
   Whoever violates Section
1505.02 shall be fined not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first
offense and not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each subsequent
offense. 
ARTICLE 1509
Outdoor Fires
1509.01   Permit required.
1509.02   On private property.
1509.03   Dangerous fires; unsafe incinerators.
1509.04   Prevention of embers, from being blown.
1509.05   Burning in violation of air pollution regulations prohibited.
1509.06   Outdoor wood-burning furnaces.
1509.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Authority to regulate  - see W.Va. Code 8-12-5(15)
 
 
1509.01  PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall burn or cause or permit to be burned, on any private or
public property outside of any building, any paper, trash, shavings, grass,
brush or other combustible material unless a burning permit is first obtained
from the City Manager or someone designated by the City Manager to issue
permits, except as provided in Section
1509.02.
(Ord. 1990-8.  Passed 7-17-90.)
1509.02  ON PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   No person, without a permit, shall burn, cause or permit to be burned, on
private property, outside of any building, any paper, trash or other
combustible materials; provided, that such burning is done in an approved
incinerator or container so constructed as to prevent embers or burning paper
or other combustible material from being cast upon or blown upon any public or
private property; and provided further that such burning is done between the
hours of 5:00 p.m., and 8:00 p.m.  (Ord. 1990-8.  Passed 7-17-90.)
1509.03  DANGEROUS FIRES; UNSAFE INCINERATORS.
   (a)   When, in the opinion of the City Manager, any fire, inside or outside
of any building, is of such character, and is so located or controlled as to
put in danger of fire any building, structure or combustible material, then no
person, having started, caused or permitted such fire shall fail to immediately
extinguish the fire after having been notified to cease such burning.
   (b)   When, in the opinion of the City Manager, any incinerator or other
container used for burning, whether located inside or outside of any building,
is such that it will not adequately prevent embers or burning material from
being discharged or blown therefrom, and therefore endangers buildings or other
property, then no person shall use or permit to be used such incinerator or
container for burning after having been notified to cease.
(Ord. 1990-8.  Passed 7-17-90.)
1509.04  PREVENTION OF EMBERS, FROM BEING BLOWN.
   (a)   No person shall burn, or cause or permit to be burned, any paper,
trash or combustible material without taking due and proper precaution to
prevent embers or burning paper or other combustible material from being blown
or cast upon any public or private property.
   (b)   No person shall burn or cause to be burned any garbage, rags, tar or
other substance or material which will give off, or which is liable to give
off, obnoxious or offensive smoke, soot or odors.  (Ord. 1990-8.  Passed 7-17-
90.)
1509.05  BURNING IN VIOLATION OF AIR POLLUTION REGULATIONS  PROHIBITED.
   No person under any condition shall burn or cause to be burned, within this
City, any paper, trash, refuse, combustible material or other substance which
will give off, or which is liable to give off sulfur oxides, nitrogen oxide,
carbon monoxide, hydrocarbons, obnoxious or offensive odors, smoke or
particulate matter in quantities which are in excess of the standards as
prescribed by the regulations of the West Virginia Air Pollution Control
Commission.
(Ord. 1990-8.  Passed 7-17-90.)
1509.06 OUTDOOR WOOD-BURNING FURNACES.
   (a)   For purposes of this section, “outdoor wood-burning furnace” means an
accessory structure or appliance designed to be located outside a dwelling
house or other building on a tract of real estate and designed to transfer or
provide heat, via liquid or other means, through the burning of wood or solid
waste, for heating spaces in any structure or appliance on the premises other
than where such structure or appliance is located, or for heating domestic,
swimming pools, hot tub or Jacuzzi water.  “Outdoor wood-burning furnace” does
not include a fire pit or wood- fired barbecue.
   (b)   No person shall construct, install, establish, modify, operate or use
an outdoor wood-burning furnace, unless the outdoor wood-burning furnace
complies with all of the following:
      (1)   The outdoor wood-burning furnace, as installed, is at least two
hundred feet from the nearest residential structure, including without
limitation, houses, garages, or other accessory buildings, not serviced by the
outdoor wood- burning furnace;
      (2)   Installation of the chimney of the outdoor wood-burning furnace is
at a height that is more than the height of the roof peaks of the residences
that are located within five hundred feet of the outdoor wood-burning furnace,
which residences are not serviced by the outdoor wood-burning furnace, provided
the chimney height is not more than fifty-five feet.
      (3)   No other materials are burned in the outdoor wood-burning furnace
other than wood that has not been chemically treated; and
      (4)   Installation and operation of the outdoor wood-burning furnace is
in accordance with the manufacturer’s written instructions, provided such
instructions do not conflict with the provisions of this section.
      (5)   Regulations issued by the West Virginia Air Pollution Control
Commission.
   (c)   Any person who operates an outdoor wood-burning furnace in violation
of this section shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor, and fined not more than
one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00).  Each day of operation of such outdoor
wood-burning furnace in violation of this section shall be deemed a separate
violation.
(Ord. 2014-3.  Passed 6-17-14.)
1509.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: See Section
101.99 for general Codified Ordinances penalty.)
(Ord. 1990-8.  Passed 7-17-90.)

ARTICLE 1705
Building Permits
1705.01   Definitions.
1705.02   Standards for construction, repair, alteration, etc., of buildings
and other structures and adoption of certain state codes.
1705.03   Gas Code.
1705.04   Fire limits.
1705.05   Building and Safety Inspector generally.
1705.06   Powers and duties of Building and Safety Inspector; withdrawal of
building permit.
1705.07   Permit required.
1705.08   Application; contents.
1705.09   Department head review; review by Building and Safety Inspector.
1705.10   Review by common council upon Building and Safety Inspector’s refusal
to grant permit.
1705.11   Issuance; display.
1705.12   Fee schedule generally.
1705.13   Exemptions and variances.
1705.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
Building regulations - see W.Va. Code 8-12-13
Permits for construction and alteration - see W.Va. Code 8-12-14
Municipal inspection - see W.Va. Code 8-12-15
 
 
1705.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases, wherever
appearing in any technical code adopted by this article, shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
   (a)   Building Department.  The office of the Building and Safety Inspector.
   (b)   Building Official.  The Building and Safety Inspector or his
authorized representative.
   (c)   Carport.  An open-sided, roofed shelter for motor vehicle(s).
   (d)   Chief Administrator.  The Mayor.
   (e)   Chief Appointing Authority.  The Mayor, with the approval of the
common council, when such approval is required.
   (f)   Electrical Inspector.  The Building and Safety Inspector or his
authorized representative, or such other person who may be charged with the
duty of administering and enforcing the provisions of the Electrical Code, or
his authorized representative.
   (g)   Legal Department.  The City Attorney.
   (h)   Local Governing Body.  The common council.
   (i)   Municipality.  The City of St. Marys.
   (j)   Structure.  A walled and roofed building (including a gas or liquid
storage tank, and a manufactured home) that is principally above ground.
      (Ord. 2001-8.  Passed 7-3-01.)
1705.02  STANDARDS FOR CONSTRUCTION, REPAIR, ALTERATION, ETC., OF BUILDINGS AND
OTHER STRUCTURES AND ADOPTION OF  CERTAIN STATE CODES.
   In the construction, repair, alteration, moving or demolition of any
building or other structure, or any part of any building or other structure,
the specifications to be met, the materials to be used, the methods to be
employed and the standards of workmanship, shall conform to the standards set
forth in the following state codes, which said state codes are adopted by
reference as though they were copied herein fully: Section 13, Chapter 12,
Chapter 8 of the Code of West Virginia, 1931, as amended, and the State
Building Code as provided for in Section 5b, Article 3, Chapter 29 of the Code
of West Virginia, 1931, as amended.
(Ord. 2001-8.  Passed 7-3-01.)
1705.03  GAS CODE.
   All provisions and requirements of the Southern Standard Gas Code, 1979
edition, insofar as such provisions are applicable to the City, are hereby
adopted and made a part of this chapter as fully as though set out herein.  It
shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to comply with such code. 
Copies of such code shall be kept on file in the office of the City Recorder. 
(Ord. 2001-8.  Passed 7-3-01.)
1705.04  FIRE LIMITS.
   The entire area of the City within the corporate boundaries is hereby
established as the fire limits of the City.  (Ord. 2001-8.  Passed 7-3-01.)
1705.05  BUILDING AND SAFETY INSPECTOR GENERALLY.
   The office of Building and Safety Inspector is hereby created.  Until such
time as the common council may provide for the appointment of a qualified
person to devote his full time to the duties of such office, the Mayor, with
approval of the common council, shall designate an appropriate City officer or
officers as ex officio building and safety inspector.  The Building and the
Safety Inspector shall have the powers and perform the duties of such office as
provided by state law, this Code and/or other ordinances or by resolution of
the common council.  (Ord. 2001- 8.  Passed 7-3-01.)
1705.06  POWERS AN DUTIES OF BUILDING AND SAFETY INSPECTOR; WITHDRAWAL OF
BUILDING PERMIT.
   (a)   At any time during the tenure of any building project contemplated by
this article, the Building and Safety Inspector shall have the right to enter
upon the premises of such project in order to determine whether the
requirements prescribed in Sections
1705.02 and
1705.03 are being observed.  If, in the opinion of the Building and Safety
Inspector, the holder of the building permit is not operating in conformity
with such code requirements, the Building and Safety Inspector shall have the
right to withdraw the building permit from the holder thereof and thereby order
the project terminated until such time as the identified violations shall have
been corrected.
   (b)   In the event that any person shall begin work for which a building
permit is required without benefit of such permit or in the event the person
from whom such building permit shall have been withdrawn shall continue
building operations notwithstanding withdrawal of his building permit, such
fact shall be immediately reported to the common council.  Upon such report,
the common council may, in its discretion, instruct the Building and Safety
Inspector to make complaint of his violation, in due and proper form before the
municipal court judge, seeking the issuance of a Warrant for violation(s) of
this article.
(Ord. 2001-8.  Passed 7-3-01.)
1705.07  PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (a)   A permit shall be obtained from the Building and Safety Inspector
before beginning construction, alteration or repairs, other than ordinary
repairs, using application forms furnished by the City Recorder.
   (b)   Ordinary repairs are nonstructural repairs and do not include addition
to, alteration of, or replacement or relocation of water supply, sewer,
drainage, gas, waste, vent or similar piping, electrical wiring, or mechanical
or other work for which a permit is required by the building official.  (Ord.
2001-8.  Passed 7-3-01.)
1705.08  APPLICATION; CONTENTS.
   No person shall construct, alter or add to any building unless he shall have
first obtained from the recorder of the common council a permit, the
application for which provide a listing of the following:
   (a)   A description of the land upon which the proposed building is to be
erected or work is to be done, either by lot, block or tract or by a similar
general description that will readily identify and definitely locate the
property, building or work.
   (b)   The purposes for which such building will be used when so erected or
constructed, or in the case of alteration or repair of any such existing
building or structure, the uses and purposes for which the same will be devoted
after such repair and alteration.
   (c)   Copies of plans and specifications of the proposed building to be
constructed or erected, or in the case of repair and alteration, plans and
specifications of the proposed alterations and repairs; or in either instance,
if plans and specifications are not available, a full and distinct statement as
to the character, type and size of the building to be constructed or erected,
or a full and distinct statement of the character, type and extent of the
proposed alterations and repairs, as the case may be.
   (d)   If such application is for a permit to move any such building or
structure, such application shall distinctly and fully set for the existing
location of the lot, tract or property upon which such building or structure is
located and a similar description of the lot, tract or property to which such
building will be moved; and when the application is for a permit to demolish an
existing building or structure, such application shall plainly set forth the
manner of such demolition and further state when disposition is to be made of
the materials resulting therefrom.
   (e)   If any applicant for a building permit be a contractor, as that term
is defined in this Code, then such applicant must furnish proof with his
application of current valid contractor’s licenses issued both by the State of
West Virginia and the City of St. Marys.
   (f)   If the plans and specifications of proposed construction, alteration
or addition show work of an electrical nature to be performed, then the
applicant for permit must furnish proof that such work will be performed by a
person duly and validly licensed as an electrician by the State of West
Virginia, except a person who performs electrical work with respect to any
property owned or leased by such person.
   (g)   In accepting a permit from the Building and Safety Inspector, the
applicant shall agree to indemnify and hold the City harmless against all
claims, warrants, demands, causes of action or suits arising from or occasioned
by the work which shall be the subject of the permit.  (Ord. 2001-8.  Passed 7-
3-01.)
1705.09  DEPARTMENT HEAD REVIEW; REVIEW BY BUILDING AND SAFETY INSPECTOR.
   Upon filing an application for a permit for any new building or structure or
moving of a building or structure, the pertinent department heads (water-sewer-
fire-street-electric) shall review and approve the same.  After such
application is reviewed, where necessary, the Building and Safety Inspector
shall pass upon the same and if the Building and Safety Inspector considers
that such construction, alteration or repair or the moving or demolition of any
such building or structure, as the case may be, will not constitute an
extraordinary fire hazard within the City limits and that such construction,
alteration and repair will not be detrimental to the morals and health of the
City and its residents, he shall issue and grant such permit without
unnecessary delay.  (Ord. 2001-8.  Passed 7-3-01.)
1705.10  REVIEW BY COMMON COUNCIL UPON BUILDING AND SAFETY INSPECTOR’S REFUSAL
TO GRANT PERMIT.
   If the Building and Safety Inspector shall, in any instance, refuse to grant
a building permit after the filing of an application, the applicant shall have
the right to apply to the common council, at its next regular meeting, for a
review of the action of the Building and Safety Inspector in so refusing such
permit, in which event the common council shall either refuse or grant such
permit after proper hearing of the matters involved, and their action in that
respect shall be final.  (Ord. 2001-8.  Passed 7-3-01.)
1705.11  ISSUANCE; DISPLAY.
   There shall be issued to the applicant a building permit, which permit shall
bear the signature of the Building and Safety Inspector and the above mentioned
department heads.  Such permit shall be displayed on the land or structure
being built, remodeled, altered or demolished.  (Ord. 2001-8.  Passed 7-3-01.)
1705.12  FEE SCHEDULE GENERALLY.
   The common council shall, by resolution, promulgate a schedule of fees to be
charged for building permits issued pursuant to this article and for
inspections required by the terms of such permits, and may, by resolution,
legislate such building permit requirements as may be deemed appropriate. 
(Ord. 2001-8.  Passed 7-3-01.)
1705.13  EXEMPTIONS AND VARIANCES.
   (a)   Notwithstanding any other provision of this article to the contrary, a
building permit fee as prescribed in Section
1705.12 shall not be required of any person coming within the jurisdiction of
this article in the event the applicant therefor shall be a unit or subdivision
of government or agency of government, whether federal, state, local or
otherwise, or person acting in behalf of such unit or subdivision of
government, whether federal, state, local or otherwise; provided, that any such
person coming within the jurisdiction of this article shall be required to
obtain a building permit as provided in the article, notwithstanding the cost
of the project.
   (b)   Nothing herein contained shall be construed to prohibit any person
coming within the jurisdiction of this article to petition the common council
for a variance in respect of any duty or rule imposed upon such person by this
Code relative to any of the various requirements thereof.  (Ord. 2001-16. 
Passed 12-4-01.)
1705.99  PENALTY.
   Any person or legal entity which shall erect any building or structure,
enlarge, alter or repair any existing building or structure or move or demolish
any such building or structure, within the meaning of this article, without
having first applied for and obtained a permit as required by this article, or
having obtained such permit and thereafter had same withdrawn as provided for
under Section
1705.06 hereof, and continues such work without such permit, shall be deemed
guilty of such offense, and upon conviction thereof shall be fined not more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and not less than two hundred dollars
($200.00) for each offense.  (Ord. 2001-8.  Passed 7-3-01.)
ARTICLE 1709

1709.06   Specific requirements.
1709.07   Administration.
1709.08   Appeals.
1709.09   Government actions.
1709.10   Severability and municipal liability.
1709.99   Penalties.
CROSS REFERENCES
Treatment of streams to prevent floods - see W.Va. Code 7-1-3(u)
Flood plain area management - see W.Va. Code 7-1-3(v)
Flood control projects - see W.Va. Code 8-30-1
 
 
1709.01 GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   (a)   Authority. 
      (1)   The provisions of this Ordinance have been prepared with the
intention of meeting the requirements of the National Flood Insurance Act of
1968 (42 U.S.C. 4001 et seq.) amended by the Congress of the United States
through the 15th of February, 1975 (Public Law 91-152),
      (2)   Authority to adopt, administer and enforce this Ordinance is vested
in the City of Saint Marys pursuant to West Virginia State Codes 8-12-14, 7-1-
3n, 7-1-3v and 7-1-3kk and/or West Virginia State Code 8A-4-2, 8A-5-7, 8A-7- 2.
   (b)   Intent.  The intent of this Ordinance is to:
      (1)   Promote the general health, welfare, and safety of the Community.
      (2)   Encourage the utilization of appropriate construction practices in
order to prevent or minimize flood damage in the future and protect natural
drainage.
      (3)   Minimize danger to public health and safety by protecting water
supply and sanitary sewage disposal in cooperation with the County Sanitarian.
      (4)   Assure that the County Assessor obtains information concerning
improvement of real property as required by WV State Code 11-3-3A.
      (5)   Assure that County E-911 addresses are obtained to maintain the
currency of established emergency response dispatch systems.
      (6)   Reduce financial burdens imposed on City of Saint Marys, its
governmental units, and its residents, by preventing the unwise design and
construction of development in areas subject to flooding.
   (c)   Abrogation and Greater Restrictions.  This Ordinance supersedes any
ordinance currently in effect in flood prone areas.  Any ordinance, however,
shall remain in full force and effect to the extent that its provisions are
more restrictive.
   (d)   Applicability.  It shall be unlawful for any contractor, person,
partnership, business, or corporation to undertake or cause to be undertaken,
any development, new construction, substantial improvement, repair of
substantial damage, or the placement or relocation of any structure (including
manufactured homes) within City of Saint Marys, unless a permit application has
been completed and a permit or certificate of compliance has been obtained from
the Floodplain Administrator.  In addition, where land partially or fully in
the special flood hazard area is to be subdivided, utilized for a manufactured
home park or subdivision or otherwise developed as defined in this Ordinance, a
site plan with elevation data shall be submitted to, and approved by, the
Floodplain Administrator prior to any development.
   Provision of all other codes, ordinances, and regulations shall be
applicable insofar as they are consistent with the provisions of this Ordinance
and the community's need to minimize the hazards and damage resulting from
flooding.
   (e)   Matters Not Provided for Specifically.  Where conditions are
encountered that are not specifically provided for herein, the Floodplain
Administrator shall determine the applicability of the provisions of this
Ordinance in accordance with its intent, and shall require the applicant to
take appropriate measures pursuant to such determination.
(Ord. 2014-01.  Passed 2-18-14.)
1709.02  INTERPRETATIONS AND DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   Interpretations.  For the purpose of this Ordinance, the following
interpretations shall apply:
      (1)   Words used in the present tense include the future tense
      (2)   The singular includes the plural.
      (3)   The plural includes the singular.
      (4)   The word "person" includes a corporation, unincorporated
association or partnership as well as an individual.
      (5)   The term "shall" or "will" is always mandatory.
      (6)   The word "building" or "structure" shall be construed as if
followed by the phrase "or part thereof".
      (7)   The word "Ordinance" shall refer to the Floodplain Ordinance.
   (b)   Definitions.  Unless specifically defined below, words and phrases
used in this Ordinance shall be interpreted so as to give this Ordinance it's
most reasonable application.
      (1)   Appurtenant Structure.  A structure on the same parcel of property
as the principal structure and the use of which is incidental to the use of the
principal structure.  This does not include a gas or liquid storage tank.
      (2)   Base Flood.  Means the flood having a one percent chance of being
equaled or exceeded in any given year.
      (3)   Base Flood Elevation (BFE).  The water surface elevation of the
base flood in relation to the datum specified on City of Saint Marys's Flood
Insurance Rate Map. For the purposes of this Ordinance, the one hundred (100)
year flood or 1% annual chance flood.
      (4)   Basement.  Any area of the building having its floor subgrade
(below ground level) on all sides.
      (5)   Certificate of Compliance.  A certification that all development is
in compliance with the provisions of this Ordinance.
      (6)   Compensatory storage.  An artificially excavated, hydraulically
equivalent volume of storage within the special flood hazard area used to
balance the loss of natural flood storage capacity when artificial fill or
structures are placed within the special flood hazard area.
      (7)   Contractor - WV State Code 21-11-3(c).  A person who in any
capacity for compensation, other than as an employee of another, undertakes,
offers to undertake, purports to have the capacity to undertake, or submits a
bid to construct, alter, repair, add to, subtract from, improve, move, wreck or
demolish any building, highway, road, railroad, structure or excavation
associated with a project, development or improvement, or to do any part
thereof, including the erection of scaffolding or other structures or works in
connection therewith, where the cost of the undertaking is one thousand dollars
or more.  Contractor includes a construction manager who performs management
and counseling services on a construction project for a professional fee.
   Contractor does not include:
         A.   One who merely furnishes materials or supplies without
fabricating or consuming them in the construction project.
         B.   A person who personally performs construction work on the site of
real property which the person owns or leases whether for commercial or
residential purposes;
         C.   A person who is licensed or registered as a professional and who
functions under the control of any other licensing or regulatory board, whose
primary business is real estate sales, appraisal, development, management and
maintenance, who acting in his or her respective professional capacity and any
employee of such professional, acting in the course of his or her employment,
performs any work which may be considered to be performing contracting work
         D.   A pest control operator licensed under the provisions of section
seven, article sixteen-a, chapter nineteen of the West Virginia Code to engage
in the application of pesticides for hire, unless the operator also performs
structural repairs exceeding one thousand dollars on property treated for
insect pests; or
         E.   A corporation, partnership or sole proprietorship whose primary
purpose is to prepare construction plans and specifications used by the
contractors defined in this section and who employs full time a registered
architect licensed to practice in this State or a Registered Professional
Engineer licensed to practice in this State. Contractor also does not include
employees of such corporation, partnership or sole proprietorship.
      (8)   Critical Facility.  Any facility in which, even a slight chance of
flooding is too great a threat. Typical critical facilities include hospitals,
fire stations, police stations, storage of critical records, and similar
facilities. These should be given special consideration when formulating
regulatory alternatives and floodplain management plans. A critical facility
should not be located in a special flood hazard area if at all possible. If a
critical facility must be located in a special flood hazard area it should be
provided a higher level of protection so that it can continue to function and
provide services during a flood.
      (9)   Development.  Any man-made change to improved or unimproved real
estate, including but not limited to buildings or other structures, mining,
dredging, filling, grading, paving, excavation or drilling operations or
storage of equipment or materials.
      (10)   Flood.  A general and temporary inundation of normally dry land
areas.
      (11)   Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM).  The official map on which the
Federal Emergency Management Agency has delineated both the special flood
hazard areas and the risk premium zones applicable to City of Saint Marys. A
firm that has been made available digitally is called a Digital Flood Insurance
Rate Map (DFIRM).
      (12)   Flood Insurance Study.  The official report in which the Federal
Emergency Management Agency has provided flood profiles, floodway information,
and water surface elevations.
      (13)   Floodplain. 
         A.   A relatively flat or low land area adjoining a river, stream, or
watercourse which is subject to partial or complete inundation;
         B.   An area subject to the unusual and rapid accumulation or runoff
of surface waters from any source.
      (14)   Floodway.  The channel of a river or other watercourse and the
adjacent land area that must be reserved to discharge the base flood without
increasing the water surface elevation of that flood more than one foot at any
point.
      (15)   Flood proofing.  Any combination of structural and non-structural
additions, changes or adjustments to structures which reduce or eliminate flood
damage to real estate or improved real property, water and sanitary facilities,
structures and their contents.
      (16)   Freeboard.  A factor of safety usually expressed in feet above a
flood level for purposes of floodplain management. Freeboard tends to
compensate for unknown factors that may contribute uncertainty to flood heights
of any given flood and floodway condition, such as wave action, blockage at
stream crossings, and increased runoff  from urbanization of the watershed.
Freeboard also tends to lower the cost of flood insurance.
      (17)   Highest Adjacent Grade (HAG).  The highest natural elevation of
the ground surface immediately adjacent to the development or structure
foundation.  This is primarily used during insurance rating in approximated
floodplains.
      (18)   Historic Structure.  Any structure that is:
         A.   Listed individually in the National Register of Historic Places
(a listing maintained by the Department of Interior) or preliminarily
determined by the Secretary of the Interior as meeting the requirements for
individual listing on the National Register;
         B.   Certified or preliminarily determined by the Secretary of the
Interior as contributing to the historical significance of a registered
historic district or a district preliminarily determined by the Secretary to
qualify as a registered historic district
         C.   Individually listed on a state inventory of historic places in
states with historic preservation programs which have been approved by the
Secretary of the Interior; or,
         D.   Individually listed on a local inventory of historic places in
communities with historic preservation programs that have been certified
either:
            1.   By an approved state program as determined by the Secretary of
the Interior; or,
            2.   Directly by the Secretary of Interior in states without
approved programs.
      (19)   Licensed Manufactured Home Retailer.  A business licensed to sell
Manufactured Homes in the State of WV as set forth in the WV State code.
      (20)   Licensed Manufactured Home Installer.  A contractor licensed to
install Manufactured Homes in WV as set forth in the WV State Code.
      (21)   Licensed Professional Surveyor.  Any person licensed by the WV
State Board of Examiners of Land Surveyors to engage in the practice of land
surveying as defined in WV State Code.
      (22)   Lowest Adjacent Grade (LAG).  The lowest natural elevation of the
ground surface immediately adjacent to the proposed development or structure
foundation. The primary use of the LAG is to determine whether the structure is
located within a special flood hazard area by comparing it to the base flood
elevation.
      (23)   Lowest Floor.  The lowest floor of the lowest enclosed area
(including basement).  An unfinished enclosure constructed with flood resistant
materials as defined in FEMA Technical Bulletin 2 and usable solely for parking
of vehicles, building access or storage in an area other than a basement area
is not considered a building's lowest floor; Provided, that such enclosure has
proper flood openings and is not built so as to render the structure in
violation of the applicable non-elevation design requirements of this
Ordinance.
      (24)   Manufactured Home.  A structure, transportable in one or more
sections, which is built on a permanent chassis and is designed for use with or
without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities.  The
term "manufactured home" does not include a "recreational vehicle".
      (25)   New Construction.  Structures for which the Start of Construction
as herein defined commenced on or after 6/03/1991 and including any subsequent
improvements to such structures. Any construction started after effective date
of City of Saint Marys's first Floodplain Ordinance adopted by City of Saint
Marys and before the effective start date of this Floodplain Management
Ordinance is subject to the ordinance in effect at the time the ordinance was
issued, provided the start of construction was within 180 days of permit
issuance.
      (26)   One-Hundred (100) Year Flood.  A flood that has one chance in one
hundred or a one percent chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year.
      (27)   Person.  Any individual or group of individuals, corporation,
partnership, association or other entity, including State and local governments
and agencies.
      (28)   Practice of Engineering.  Any service or creative work, as
described in WV State Code Article 13, the adequate performance of which
requires engineering education, training and experience in the application of
special knowledge of the mathematical, physical and engineering sciences to
such services or creative work as consultation, investigation, evaluation,
planning and design of engineering works and systems;  planning the use of land
and water; teaching of advanced engineering subjects, engineering surveys and
studies; and the review of construction for the purpose of assuring compliance
with drawings and specifications any of which embraces such services or work,
either public or private, in connection with any utilities, structures,
buildings, machines, equipment, processes, work systems, projects and
industrial or consumer products or equipment of a mechanical, electrical,
hydraulic, pneumatic or thermal nature, insofar as they involve safeguarding
life, health or property, and including such other professional services as may
be necessary to the planning, progress and completion of any engineering
services. Engineering surveys include all survey activities required to support
the sound conception, planning, design, construction, maintenance and operation
of engineered projects.
   Any person who practices any branch of the profession of engineering or who,
by verbal claim, sign, advertisement, letterhead, card or in any other way
represents himself or herself to be a Registered Professional Engineer, or by
using another title implies that he or she is a Registered Professional
Engineer or that he or she is registered under WV State Code, Article 13 or who
holds himself or herself out as able to perform, or who performs any
engineering service or work or any other service designated by the practitioner
which is recognized as engineering, is considered to practice or offer to
practice engineering within the meaning and intent of WV State Code Article 13.
      (29)   Principally Above Ground.  Where at least 51 percent of the actual
cash value of a structure, less land value, is above ground.
      (30)   Recreational Vehicle.  A vehicle which is:
         A.   Built on a single chassis;
         B.   400 square feet or less when measured at the largest horizontal
projection;
         C.   Designed to be self-propelled or permanently towable by a light
duty truck; and
         D.   Designed primarily not for use as a permanent dwelling but as
temporary living quarters for recreational, camping, travel, or seasonal use.
      (31)   Registered Professional Engineer.  A person who has been duly
